abstract.p: Eric Rosenbaum letter comments on March 4 article on old wives' tales about health

block.p: Re '' 'You'll Catch Your Death!' An Old Wives' Tale? Well . . .'' (March 4): My girlfriend and I seem to reargue this point every few weeks, usually after I've refused to put on a hat before venturing out into a cold, rainy Portland evening.

Re '' 'You'll Catch Your Death!' An Old Wives' Tale? Well . . .'' (March 4): My girlfriend and I seem to reargue this point every few weeks, usually after I've refused to put on a hat before venturing out into a cold, rainy Portland evening.
But the article also reminds me of a story of colonial America. Benjamin Franklin, a tireless experimenter, strongly believed that cold air was good for the body.

On one famous occasion when Franklin was sharing a room with John Adams, Adams asked Franklin to close the window, and Franklin proceeded to lecture Adams on his theory of the benefits of cold air. As interesting as the subject and the article are, it is reported that Adams fell asleep while Franklin was expounding.
